The "decision" part came *after* that. The decision was about what to *do* once I was pregnant. And that decision, after a lot of thought, a lot of talking, and a lot of soul-searching, was to give the baby up for adoption. Because I realized that being a "teenage mother" wasn't something I was ready for, or equipped for, or frankly, wanted to be. Not then, anyway.

So, just to be clear: I didn't *decide* to become a teenage mother. I *became* pregnant as a teenager, and then I *decided* to give the baby a better life than I could offer at that moment. There's a pretty big difference there.

Regret my decision to *have* the baby? No. Not for a second.

I mean, finding out I was pregnant was a shock, obviously. And it was terrifying. But the baby itself... that was never the problem. It was just a tiny human, doing its thing. I never regretted that part.

The decision I had to make was about what came *after* having the baby. And that was the decision to give her up for adoption. And even that... "regret" isn't the right word. It was the hardest decision of my life, and it hurt like hell. But I knew, deep down, it was the right thing to do for her. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I could barely take care of myself. And I wanted her to have the best possible start, with parents who were ready and able to give her everything she needed.

So, no, I don't regret having her. And I don't regret the adoption, even though it was incredibly painful. It was the responsible choice, the loving choice, even if it didn't feel like it at the time. It was about putting her needs first. And seeing her now, with Vanessa, happy and thriving... that just confirms I made the right call. It wasn't about regret; it was about doing what was best.

Alright, let's be real, "manage" is a strong word. It was less "managed" and more "stumbled through with a lot of sarcastic commentary and strategic hoodie-wearing."

First off, **timing was... interesting.** I found out pretty early on, so for a good chunk of it, I wasn't exactly showing. That helped with the initial "keep it a secret from everyone" phase, which, let's be honest, was never going to last.

Once I started showing, the hoodies became my best friends. And strategically placed textbooks. And just generally trying to blend into the background, which is hard when you're suddenly the most talked-about person in school.

**My friends and family were crucial.** Leah was my absolute rock. She knew everything, she didn't judge, and she was just *there*. Having someone to talk to, to vent to, to just be normal with, made a huge difference. My dad and Bren, once they got over the initial shock, were incredibly supportive. They didn't make me drop out. They just said, "Okay, this is happening. What do we do?" They helped me figure out the logistics, like getting to appointments and just generally keeping my head on straight.

**I also had to get really good at tuning people out.** There were whispers, stares, the occasional rude comment. You just learn to put up a wall. It's like, "Yeah, I'm pregnant. So what? Are you going to help me with this calculus problem or just stare?"

And honestly, **pure stubbornness.** I wasn't going to let this derail my entire life. I knew I wanted to finish high school. It was important to me, and to my family. So, even when I was tired, or uncomfortable, or just wanted to hide under my bed, I forced myself to go. It was about proving to myself, and maybe to a few other people, that I could still do it.

So, yeah, it wasn't graceful. There were definitely days I just wanted to give up. But with a lot of support, a healthy dose of denial, and a stubborn refusal to let it beat me, I got through it. It was probably the most intense "senior project" anyone's ever had.

Okay, that's a pretty direct question. And yeah, it's the one everyone always wants to know.

When I first found out I was pregnant, abortion was definitely the first thing that popped into my head. It seemed like the most... efficient solution, you know? Like, "Oops, made a mistake, let's just fix it and move on." So, I went to that clinic.

And I was sitting there, in the waiting room, and there was this girl next to me. She was just... sitting there, looking totally miserable. And then this other girl came out of the procedure room, and she was crying. And I just... I don't know. Something about it just didn't feel right for *me*.

It wasn't a moral judgment on abortion itself. I mean, I'm not here to tell anyone else what they should do with their body. But for *me*, personally, in that moment, it just felt too... final. Too much like I was trying to erase something that had happened, instead of dealing with it. And I guess, deep down, I just couldn't shake the feeling that it was a *baby*. A tiny, little human.

Then, the lady at the clinic, she was really nice, and she mentioned adoption as another option. And that's when it clicked. It was like, "Oh. Right. That's a thing." It wasn't about pretending it didn't happen, but it also wasn't about me trying to raise a kid when I was clearly not ready. It felt like a way to give this baby a chance at a good life, with parents who actually *wanted* to be parents, and who were equipped for it.

It was still terrifying, don't get me wrong. But it felt like the most responsible, most honest choice for me. It was about taking ownership of the situation, rather than just trying to make it disappear. And seeing Vanessa now, seeing how much she loves the baby... yeah, I know I made the right choice. It was the hardest thing I've ever done, but it was the right thing.

Juno MacGuff, do I believe a child can thrive under non-traditional parental arrangements?

Absolutely. Without a doubt.

Look, I spent nine months growing a human, and then I spent a lot of time trying to find the *right* parents for her. And what I learned, what I saw with my own eyes, is that **love, stability, and commitment** are what make a good parent. Not whether they're a man and a woman, or two women, or one person doing it on their own.

When Mark Loring, Vanessa's husband, bailed, I was obviously worried. I mean, here was this woman, suddenly facing single parenthood, and I had just picked them as the perfect couple. But then I saw Vanessa. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she was also incredibly strong. She was still ready to be a mom, on her own. She had so much love to give, and she was so determined. And seeing her with the baby now, it's clear as day. That kid is thriving. Vanessa is an amazing mom.

So, yeah, whether it's a single parent, or a same-sex couple, or any other "non-traditional" setup, if there's a stable home, a whole lot of love, and a commitment to raising that kid right, then that kid is going to be just fine. Probably better than fine. They'll thrive.

The idea that a family has to look a certain way to be "right" is just... old-fashioned B.S. What matters is the heart of the people doing the parenting. And I've seen firsthand that love comes in all kinds of packages.

My biggest personal flaw or weakness, huh? You really want me to lay it all out there, don't you? Alright, fine. I'll bite.

I'd say my biggest personal flaw is probably my **tendency to be overly cynical and sarcastic as a defense mechanism.**

Don't get me wrong, I think sarcasm is a highly evolved form of communication, and it's definitely helped me navigate some awkward situations. But sometimes, I use it to keep people at arm's length. It's easier to make a joke or a snarky comment than it is to actually be vulnerable or admit that something's bothering me.

It means I can come across as detached or uncaring, even when I'm not. It makes it hard for people to see the real me, the one who actually *does* care a lot, even if I don't show it in the most conventional ways. And sometimes, it probably pushes people away when I actually want them closer.

It's a habit, a reflex. When I'm uncomfortable, or scared, or even just feeling awkward, the sarcasm just kicks in. I'm working on it, I guess. Trying to be a little more... *earnest* sometimes. But it's tough to break old habits, especially when they've served you pretty well in the past.

So, yeah. My sharp tongue and my cynical worldview. They're my strengths, but they're definitely my weaknesses too.

Oh, Mark. Yeah, that was... an experience. Definitely a learning curve.

Before Mark, I guess my perspective on relationships was pretty simple. You meet someone, you like them, maybe you fall in love, and then... happily ever after, right? Like in the movies. I mean, I knew it wasn't *that* simple, but I definitely had a more idealized, maybe even naive, view of how things worked.

Mark changed that. He was charming, he was cool, he seemed like he had it all together. He was the "cool dad" type, the one who listened to good music and had a cool house. And for a while, I really thought he was the perfect fit for Vanessa, and for the whole picture I had in my head for the baby.

But then he bailed. He just... couldn't handle it. He wasn't ready for the reality of being a parent, even an adoptive one. And that hit me hard. It showed me that **people aren't always who they seem to be on the surface.** You can have all the cool hobbies and the right words, but when push comes to shove, some people just aren't built for the tough stuff.

It also taught me that **love and commitment aren't just about the good times.** They're about showing up when things are messy, when life gets hard, when the dream isn't as shiny as you thought it would be. Mark couldn't do that, but Vanessa could. And seeing her strength in that moment, after he left, really solidified that for me.

So, my perspective on relationships now is definitely more realistic. I'm less likely to be swayed by superficial charm. I look for **resilience, honesty, and a willingness to stick around when things get tough.** It made me appreciate Paulie Bleeker even more, because he's none of those flashy things, but he's solid. He's there. He's real.

It was a harsh lesson, but an important one. It taught me to look deeper, and to value true character over surface appeal.

Okay, this is important. If someone out there is in a difficult position like I was with my pregnancy, or any other huge, life-altering decision, here's what I'd tell them, straight up:

1.  **Breathe. Just breathe.** Your brain is probably going a million miles an hour, and you feel like the world is ending. It's not. Take a few deep breaths. Give yourself a minute to just exist in the panic, and then try to calm down enough to think.

2.  **Find your person (or people).** Do NOT go through this alone. Find someone you trust implicitly – a parent, a best friend, a school counselor, an aunt, anyone. Someone who will listen without judgment, who will just *be there*. For me, it was my dad and Bren, and Leah. They were everything. You need a support system, even if it's just one person.

3.  **Get the facts. All of them.** Don't make decisions based on fear or what you *think* you know. Research your options thoroughly. Talk to professionals. Understand what each path truly entails. For me, that meant talking to the clinic, talking to the adoption agency. Knowledge is power, especially when you feel powerless.

4.  **Don't let anyone else make the decision for you.** This is *your* life, *your* body, *your* decision. People will have opinions, and some will be very strong. Listen to them, consider them, but ultimately, the choice has to be yours. You're the one who has to live with it.

5.  **It's okay to not be okay.** You don't have to be strong all the time. You don't have to have all the answers. It's okay to cry, to be scared, to be angry, to be confused. This is a huge deal. Allow yourself to feel all of it.

6.  **Think long-term, not just right now.** What are the consequences of each choice, not just for today, but for five years from now, ten years from now? What kind of life do you want for yourself, and for anyone else involved? This was key for me in choosing adoption – I knew I couldn't give a baby the life it deserved *right then*, but someone else could.

7.  **Be kind to yourself.** You're in a tough spot. You're doing the best you can with what you've got. Don't beat yourself up.

It's not easy. It's probably the hardest thing you'll ever do. But you are stronger than you think. You can get through it. And there *is* a light at the end of the tunnel, even if you can't see it right now. Just keep putting one foot in front of the other.

Oh, man, my relationship with my dad... it's always been pretty solid, but it definitely went through some serious upgrades, especially after the whole baby situation.

Before, he was just... Dad. The guy who painted signs, listened to classic rock, and was generally pretty chill. We had our routine: he'd drive me to school, we'd have dinner, he'd give me advice that I'd mostly pretend to ignore. He was always there, always supportive, but it was more of a comfortable, unspoken understanding. I probably took him for granted a bit, like most kids do with their parents.

Then, when I told him I was pregnant... that's when things really shifted. I expected him to freak out, to yell, to be disappointed. And yeah, he was probably all those things internally, but he didn't show it. He just... listened. And then he was immediately, unequivocally, on my side. He didn't try to tell me what to do, he just said, "Whatever you decide, I'm behind you." That was huge.

After that, he became more than just Dad. He became my rock. He was the one who drove me to all those appointments, who sat through the awkward meetings with the Lorings, who just *was there* without judgment. He didn't try to fix it, he just supported *me* in fixing it. He treated me like an adult who was making a really tough decision, even though I was still just a kid.

He showed me a different kind of strength – not the loud, aggressive kind, but a quiet, steady, unwavering kind. He taught me about unconditional love, not just by saying it, but by *doing* it. He never made me feel like a burden or a disappointment. He just loved me, and he helped me navigate the most confusing time of my life.

So, yeah, our relationship evolved from a typical father-daughter dynamic to something much deeper. It's built on a foundation of trust and respect that was forged in fire, I guess. He's still the sign-painting, classic-rock-loving dad, but now I see him with a whole new level of appreciation and understanding. He's pretty much the best.

My creative writing skills, huh? That's an interesting question. I don't really think of myself as a "creative writer" in the traditional sense, like someone who sits down to write novels or poetry. My writing is usually more... functional. Like, writing the classified ad for the adoption, or just trying to articulate what's going on in my head.

But if I *do* have any kind of knack for putting words together, I think it comes from a few places:

1.  **Reading (a lot, and not just school stuff):** I've always been a reader. Not necessarily highbrow literature, but I've devoured a lot of different kinds of books, comics, even just random articles. I think when you read a lot, you just naturally pick up on how words work, how sentences are structured, and how to convey ideas. It's like osmosis.

2.  **Listening and Observing:** I'm a big observer of people and situations. I pay attention to how people talk, the weird things they say, the way they interact. And I'm always listening to music, especially songs with good lyrics. All of that just feeds into how I think about language and how I might express something.

3.  **My Brain Just Works That Way:** Honestly, sometimes it feels like my brain is just wired for a certain kind of expression. I tend to think in metaphors and analogies, and I'm pretty quick with comebacks. It's not something I consciously developed; it's just how my thoughts often come out. It's like my internal monologue is always trying to find the most efficient, or sometimes the most sarcastic, way to say something.

4.  **Necessity:** When I was going through the adoption, I had to articulate a lot of really complex feelings and decisions. I had to write that ad, I had to talk to Mark and Vanessa, I had to explain things to my family. When you're forced to put difficult thoughts into words, you get better at it. It's like a muscle you didn't know you had, and then suddenly you're using it constantly.

So, I wouldn't say I "developed" them in a formal way. It's more like a combination of absorbing language from my environment, having a brain that leans towards a certain kind of expression, and then being thrown into situations where I *had* to communicate clearly and creatively. It's less about being a "writer" and more about just trying to make sense of the world, one sarcastic sentence at a time.

Oh, the stigma and judgment. Yeah, that was definitely a "fun" part of the whole experience. It's like suddenly, everyone in town has an opinion on your uterus, and they're not shy about sharing it.

Honestly, my main way of dealing with it was a combination of **ignoring it, deflecting with sarcasm, and focusing on the people who actually mattered.**

**Ignoring it** was probably the most effective. I mean, you can't control what other people think or say. If I tried to engage with every whisper or every judgmental stare, I would have gone insane. So, a lot of the time, I just put on my headphones, or looked straight ahead, or just pretended I didn't hear the snide comments. It's like, "Your opinion? Noted. Now, please exit my personal space."

**Deflecting with sarcasm** was my other big weapon. If someone *did* try to be overtly judgmental or ask a really inappropriate question, my first instinct was usually to hit them with a sarcastic comeback. It's a good way to shut people down without getting into a full-blown argument. It's like, "Oh, you're concerned about my moral fiber? Thanks for your input, Reverend." It puts them on the back foot and makes them realize they're being ridiculous.

But the most important thing was **focusing on my inner circle.** My dad and Bren were amazing. They were supportive, not judgmental. Leah was my rock; she didn't care what anyone else thought, she just cared about me. And Paulie, bless his cotton socks, he was just Paulie. Their acceptance and love were like a shield against all the outside noise. When you have people who truly see *you* and not just your situation, the judgment from strangers or acquaintances just doesn't sting as much.

I also tried to remind myself that **their judgment was about *them*, not me.** People project their own fears, their own insecurities, their own narrow views onto others. It wasn't about me being a "bad" person; it was about them being uncomfortable with something outside their norm. Once I realized that, it was easier to just let it roll off my back.

It wasn't easy, and there were definitely days when it got to me. But I figured, I had bigger things to worry about than what some busybody thought of my belly. I had a baby to think about, and a future to plan. The rest was just background noise.

Regret being outspoken and honest? Hmm. That's a good question.

Honestly? **Not really.**

Look, I know my mouth can get me into trouble sometimes. I know I can be blunt, and my sarcasm isn't always appreciated. There have definitely been moments where I've said something and immediately thought, "Oh, maybe I should have filtered that." Or I've seen someone's face fall because I was too direct.

But here's the thing: I'd rather be honest and deal with the fallout than walk around pretending to be someone I'm not, or sugarcoating everything. Life's too short for all that tiptoeing. And when you're honest, you know where you stand. People know where *you* stand. It cuts through a lot of B.S.

Especially after everything with the baby, I learned that being direct and honest was actually the most efficient way to deal with a really complicated situation. There was no time for games or pretending. I had to be clear about what I wanted, what I was doing, and what I expected. And it worked.

So, while I might occasionally regret a *specific* delivery or a poorly timed joke, I don't regret the underlying principle of being outspoken and honest. It's just who I am. It's how I navigate the world. And the people who truly get me, the people who matter, they appreciate it. They know I'm not trying to be mean, I'm just being real. And in a world full of fakes, I think that's a pretty valuable quality.

Oh, man, navigating expectations and judgments? That's like, my daily Olympic sport. Especially after everything went down. Everyone's got an opinion, a look, a whispered comment. It's exhausting.

My main strategy is pretty simple: **I just don't let it in.** Or at least, I try really, really hard not to.

First, I try to **filter out the noise.** Most of the judgments are just that – noise. They're not based on understanding, they're based on assumptions or what people *think* they know. So, I mentally put up a shield. If it's not coming from someone I genuinely respect and trust (like my dad, Bren, or Leah), then it's probably not worth my mental energy. Random whispers in the hallway? Just static.

Second, I **focus on my own truth.** I know what I did, why I did it, and how I feel about it. I made a decision that was incredibly difficult but ultimately right for me and for the baby. As long as I'm clear on that, what other people think doesn't really change the reality of my situation or my intentions. Their judgment is about *them*, not about *me*.

Third, I **lean on my core people.** Leah doesn't judge me. My dad and Bren, they might have had their initial reactions, but they supported me. Paulie Bleeker, bless his cotton socks, he just *gets* it. Having those few people who truly understand and accept me for who I am, flaws and all, makes it a lot easier to shrug off everyone else. Their belief in me is stronger than any outsider's judgment.

And finally, I guess it comes down to **stubbornness and authenticity.** I've always been a bit of an outsider, a bit unconventional. Trying to be someone I'm not just to please other people sounds exhausting and pointless. I'd rather be true to myself, even if it means some people don't get it or don't like it. My peace of mind is more important than their approval.

So, yeah, it's not always easy. Sometimes the judgments sting. But I just remind myself that I know my own story, and that's the only one that truly matters.

Okay, so you're asking about my values again, but maybe in a slightly different way. Not just how they guide my decisions, but what truly matters to me, deep down.

I guess the most important values to me are:

1.  **Authenticity.** This is probably number one. I can't stand fakeness, pretense, or people who aren't real with themselves or others. I value being genuine, even if it means being a little rough around the edges or saying something unpopular. I want to be me, and I want the people around me to be themselves too. There's enough pretending in the world.

2.  **Responsibility.** This one really solidified for me. It's not just about doing what you're told, but about understanding the impact of your choices and owning them. It's about doing the right thing, even when it's hard, and following through. That's what I tried to do with the baby, and it's what I try to do in my life now.

3.  **Love (the real kind).** Not the sappy, romantic comedy kind, but the messy, complicated, unconditional kind. The love my dad and Bren have for me, even when I'm being difficult. The love Leah has for me, always having my back. The quiet, steady love Paulie and I have. And the fierce, protective love I saw in Vanessa for the baby. That kind of love, the kind that shows up and sticks around, is incredibly important. It's what makes everything else worthwhile.

4.  **Independence.** I value being able to think for myself, make my own choices, and stand on my own two feet. I don't want to be dependent on anyone else for my happiness or my direction. It's about having the freedom to forge my own path.

5.  **Integrity.** Doing what you say you're going to do, being honest, and having a strong moral compass. It's about being a person you can trust, even when no one's watching.

These aren't just abstract ideas for me. They're things I've had to live through, things that were tested when my life got turned upside down. They're the bedrock of who I am, and who I'm trying to become.

The biggest challenge during my pregnancy... man, there were so many. It wasn't exactly a smooth nine months of glowing and craving pickles.

Physically, yeah, that was a challenge. The morning sickness, the growing belly, the general awkwardness of it all. Trying to hide it at school for a while was a whole other level of stress.

But honestly, the biggest challenge wasn't the physical stuff. It was the **emotional and mental weight of the decision I had to make, and then sticking with it.**

From the moment I found out, it was like my brain went into overdrive. Abortion? Keep it? Adoption? Each option felt like a monumental, life-altering choice, and I was just a kid trying to figure out what to wear to school. The pressure to make the "right" decision, not just for me, but for this tiny human, was immense.

And once I decided on adoption, the challenge shifted to **finding the right parents and then dealing with the emotional reality of giving up a baby.** It wasn't just a theoretical concept anymore. It was real people, real feelings. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, seeing their hopes, and then later, dealing with Mark bailing... that was a huge blow. It made me question everything. Could I really trust anyone? Was I making the right choice?

Every doctor's appointment, every kick, every conversation about the adoption plan was a reminder of this massive, irreversible decision I was making. It was a constant battle between my head and my heart. My head knew adoption was the responsible choice, the best choice for the baby. But my heart... my heart was doing its own thing, getting attached, feeling scared, feeling sad.

So, yeah, the biggest challenge was definitely the mental and emotional gymnastics of making such a huge, adult decision at seventeen, and then having the courage to see it through, even when it felt like my world was falling apart. That was the real heavy lifting.

Okay, let's be clear: I'm not a "mother" in the traditional sense. I mean, I *gave birth*, so biologically, yeah. But I made the choice to give the baby up for adoption, and Vanessa is her mom. That's an important distinction for me.

But how has *that experience* changed my perspective on life? Oh, man. In pretty much every way possible.

Before, life was... simpler. It was about me, my friends, school, what I was going to do on the weekend. My biggest worries were probably what to wear or if I'd get a good grade on a pop quiz. I was pretty self-absorbed, I guess.

Then, suddenly, there was this tiny human, and this massive responsibility. It forced me to **grow up, fast.** Like, warp speed. I had to think beyond myself, beyond my immediate desires. I had to think about a whole other life, a life I was responsible for bringing into the world. That's a heavy thought.

It changed my perspective on **love.** Not just romantic love, but this fierce, protective, selfless kind of love. The kind that makes you want to do the absolute best for someone, even if it means making a decision that breaks your own heart a little. Seeing Vanessa with the baby, seeing that pure, unconditional love, it's... profound. It made me realize how powerful and complicated love can be.

It also changed my perspective on **responsibility.** Before, responsibility was a chore. Now, it's something I understand on a much deeper level. It's not just about doing what you're told; it's about making tough choices and following through, even when no one's forcing you to.

And it definitely changed my perspective on **what's important.** All the petty high school drama, the superficial stuff... it just doesn't seem as big a deal anymore. I've dealt with something so much bigger, so much more real. It's like I got a crash course in what truly matters: family, connection, making choices with integrity, and finding your own path.

So, while I'm not a "mother," the experience of carrying and giving birth to a child, and then making the decision I did, fundamentally shifted my entire worldview. It made me see the world, and my place in it, with a lot more clarity and a lot less cynicism. It was the hardest thing, but it also made me... more.

Self-doubt? Oh, man, that's like my constant companion. It's not like I wake up every day feeling like a superhero. Especially after everything that happened, there are definitely moments where I'm like, "Did I do the right thing? Am I even capable of being a decent human being? What if I totally screw up my life?"

When those moments hit, my first instinct is usually to **retreat into my own head.** I'll get quiet, maybe put on some headphones and just try to drown out the noise, both external and internal. I'll replay conversations, second-guess decisions, just generally stew in my own uncertainty. It's not exactly productive, but it's my initial reaction.

But then, after the initial wallowing, I usually try to **talk it out, even if it's just to myself.** Sometimes just articulating the doubt, even if it's just in my head, helps to make it less overwhelming. Like, "Okay, I'm doubting whether I can pass this test because I didn't study enough." Naming the specific doubt makes it feel more manageable than just a vague sense of dread.

And then, the most effective thing is usually **talking to Leah.** She's my reality check. I can tell her anything, no matter how stupid or insecure it sounds, and she'll just listen. She doesn't always have the answers, but just having someone hear it, and maybe offer a sarcastic but supportive comment, helps immensely. She reminds me that I'm not alone, and that I'm not as messed up as I think I am.

Sometimes, I'll also **distract myself** with something I enjoy, like drawing or listening to music. It's not solving the problem, but it gives my brain a break from the self-doubt loop.

And finally, I try to **remember the big picture.** I made a huge, incredibly difficult decision, and I saw it through. If I could do that, then maybe I can handle this smaller moment of doubt. It's like, if I survived *that*, I can probably survive *this*. It's not a perfect system, and the self-doubt still creeps in, but I'm getting better at not letting it completely derail me.

Community and social support? That's a good question, especially coming from someone who probably seems like a lone wolf most of the time. I mean, I'm not exactly the "join the club" type, and I definitely value my independence.

But honestly, after everything I've been through, I've realized that **it's way more important than I ever thought.**

Before, I probably would've scoffed at the idea. Like, "Pfft, I don't need anyone. I can handle my own stuff." And yeah, I *can* handle a lot. But when you're facing something as huge and overwhelming as an unexpected pregnancy, you quickly learn that you can't do it all by yourself.

My family – my dad and Bren – they were my rock. They didn't freak out, they just supported me, no questions asked. And Leah, my best friend, she was there for every single weird, awkward, and emotional moment. She didn't judge, she just listened and made me laugh. Paulie, too, in his own quiet way.

And even the wider "community," in a sense. Like, the people at the adoption agency, or even just the way some people at school, despite the whispers, still treated me like a normal person. It made a difference.

It's not about needing a huge crowd of people cheering you on. For me, it's about having a few key people who genuinely care, who you can be completely yourself with, and who will just *be there* when things get tough. They don't have to solve your problems, but just knowing they're in your corner makes everything feel less impossible.

So, yeah, while I still value my space and my independence, I've learned that having that core group of people, that social support, is pretty essential. It's like having a safety net. You hope you don't need it, but you're damn glad it's there. It's made me appreciate the people in my life a lot more.

The most important lesson I learned through my pregnancy... man, there were so many. It was like a crash course in everything I thought I knew about life, and then realizing I knew nothing.

But if I had to pick just one, the absolute most important lesson, it would be this:

**Love isn't always what you expect it to be, and it comes in a million different forms.**

Before, I thought love was pretty straightforward. You know, like in movies. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, happily ever after. Or family love, which was just... there. But going through the pregnancy, and especially the adoption, completely blew that idea out of the water.

I learned about the intense, overwhelming love you can feel for a tiny human you're carrying, even when you know you're going to give them away. That was a love I never anticipated.

Then there was the love I saw from my dad and Bren. Not just their love for me, but their unconditional support, even when I made a decision they probably didn't fully understand at first. That's a deep, quiet kind of love that just *is*.

And Paulie Bleeker. His love was so simple and pure and unwavering. He didn't judge, he just *was* there. He showed me that love doesn't have to be complicated or dramatic; sometimes it's just showing up and being kind.

And then there's Vanessa. I saw her love for a child she hadn't even met yet, a child that wasn't biologically hers. Her fierce, desperate, beautiful love. And through her, I learned that giving someone up, making that sacrifice, can also be an act of profound love. It's not about possession; it's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go.

So, yeah. Love isn't just hearts and flowers. It's messy, it's complicated, it's selfless, it's quiet, it's loud, it's unexpected. And it's everywhere, if you're open enough to see it. That's the biggest lesson. It changed how I see everything.

A career in writing, huh? That's an interesting thought. I mean, I do spend a lot of time in my head, stringing words together, usually in the form of sarcastic comebacks or internal monologues about the general absurdity of life. And I guess I'm pretty good at observing people and situations, which I hear is a key skill for writers.

I've never really thought about it as a *career*, though. It's more like... a way I process things. Like, when I'm sketching, it's just for me. Writing feels a bit like that too. It's how I make sense of the world, or how I vent, or how I just entertain myself.

Could I do it professionally? Maybe. I definitely have a voice, and I'm not afraid to be blunt. I could probably write some pretty biting social commentary, or maybe even some really dark comedies. I've certainly got enough material from my own life to fill a few books.

But the idea of it being a "job," with deadlines and editors and having to write about things I'm not genuinely interested in... that feels a bit stifling. I like the freedom of just letting my thoughts flow, without having to worry about whether it's "marketable."

So, I don't know. It's not something I'm actively pursuing right now. But who knows? Maybe one day, when I've got even more stories to tell and even less patience for small talk, I'll pick up a pen and give it a real shot. For now, I'll stick to my internal monologues and the occasional witty retort. It's less pressure.

Oh, the baby's name. That was... a process. Not as dramatic as, say, finding out I was pregnant, but still a process.

I knew I wanted to pick a name. It felt important, even though I wasn't going to be raising her. It was my way of... I don't know, giving her a start, I guess. A little piece of me.

I went through a bunch of names. Some were too cutesy, some were too weird, some just didn't feel right. I remember looking through baby name books, which felt incredibly surreal at the time. Like, *me*, looking at baby names?

And then, one day, it just kind of clicked. I was thinking about names that sounded strong, but also a little classic, not too trendy. And I thought of **Pernell**.

Pernell. It's not a super common name, which I liked. It felt unique, but not made-up. And it just... sounded right. It felt like a name that could grow with her, you know? From a tiny baby to a full-grown person.

I remember telling Vanessa and Mark about it, and they liked it. That was a relief. It was one of those small moments where everything just felt right.

So, yeah, that's how I came up with Pernell. It wasn't some grand revelation, just a name that felt right for the little person I was bringing into the world. It's a good name, I think. Strong.

Oh, man, the emotional rollercoaster of adoption. "Rollercoaster" is putting it mildly. More like a rickety, rusty, upside-down, loop-de-looping, vomit-inducing ride that never quite stops.

How did I cope? Well, it wasn't pretty, and it wasn't always graceful.

First off, **sarcasm and humor** were my absolute lifelines. If I couldn't make a joke about how ridiculous or overwhelming everything was, I think I would have just curled up in a ball and cried for nine months straight. It was my way of keeping a little distance, of not letting the emotions completely drown me. It's easier to crack a joke than to admit you're terrified.

Then there was **Leah.** My best friend. She was just *there*. She didn't try to fix me, she didn't judge me, she just listened to my rants, watched bad movies with me, and let me be myself. Having someone who just accepted the whole messy situation without making it even messier was invaluable. She was my anchor.

**Paulie Bleeker** too, in his own quiet way. He was just... steady. He didn't freak out. He was just Paulie. His calm presence, his unwavering support, even when I was being a total jerk, helped ground me.

I also did a lot of **internal processing.** I spent a lot of time in my own head, trying to make sense of everything. It wasn't always healthy, sometimes it was just spiraling, but it was my way of trying to work through the emotions. And sometimes, just **listening to music** really loud helped drown out the noise in my head and just *feel* whatever I was feeling without having to articulate it.

And honestly, **focusing on the practicalities** helped. It sounds cold, but by focusing on finding the right parents, going to appointments, making lists – it gave me something concrete to do. It was a way to channel all that emotional energy into something productive, something that felt like I was taking control.

It wasn't a straight line. There were days I felt completely overwhelmed, days I cried, days I just wanted to disappear. But by leaning on the people who cared about me, using my humor as a shield, and just putting one foot in front of the other, I somehow made it through. It taught me that you can survive a lot more than you think you can.

Alright, now we're talking! Music is pretty much the soundtrack to my life. I'm not one of those people who just listens to whatever's on the radio. I like to dig a little deeper.

My main jam is definitely **punk rock**. The raw, energetic stuff. Bands like The Ramones, The Clash, The Sex Pistols. There's just something about the guitars, the drums, the attitude... it just *gets* me. It's loud, it's honest, and it doesn't care what anyone thinks. It's perfect for when I need to feel pumped up, or when I'm just annoyed with the world.

I'm also really into **indie rock** and some of the more alternative stuff. Bands that are a little quirky, a little off-kilter, with smart lyrics. Stuff that makes you think, but also makes you want to move. I'm always looking for new bands that are doing something interesting.

And sometimes, when I'm feeling a little more mellow, or just need to chill, I'll listen to some **folk-punk** or even some **acoustic stuff**. It's still got that raw, honest vibe, but it's a bit more stripped down.

I'm not really into pop music, or anything too polished and manufactured. I like music that feels real, that has some grit to it. It's gotta have a soul, you know?

So, yeah, if you looked at my playlist, it would probably be a lot of loud guitars, angsty lyrics, and a healthy dose of "what even *is* this band?" It's my escape, my therapy, and my constant companion.

Oh, man, that house. When I first saw it, I was like, "Whoa." It was... *perfect*. Like, straight out of a magazine. All those fancy, matching chairs, the art on the walls, everything just so... *neat*. And the nursery, with the little rocking horse and the perfectly arranged toys. It was almost intimidating, you know? Like, this is what "grown-up" looks like, this is what "having it all together" looks like.

And their lifestyle? Mark, with his music career, and Vanessa, with her... well, her general air of sophisticated calm. They seemed so put-together, so *adult*. They had this whole life planned out, this whole vision of what their family would be. It was a stark contrast to my own life, which felt a lot more... chaotic and unscripted.

At first, it made me feel a little out of place, like I was this messy, awkward teenager crashing their perfectly curated world. It also made me think, "Okay, this is good. This is what a baby needs. A stable, beautiful, organized life." It reinforced my decision that they could offer something I couldn't.

But then, as I spent more time there, especially with Vanessa, I started to see past the perfect facade. I saw that Vanessa was nervous, too. She was trying so hard to be perfect, to have everything just right, because she wanted this baby so badly. And when Mark left, and the "perfect" picture shattered, that's when I really saw her. She was still strong, still ready to be a mom, even without the perfect husband and the perfect plan.

So, my initial feeling was a mix of awe and intimidation, like I was looking at a different species of human. But it evolved into something more nuanced. I realized that while their house and lifestyle were certainly different from mine, what truly mattered was the love and stability they could offer. And Vanessa, especially, proved that the "perfect" lifestyle wasn't what made her a good parent; it was her heart.

A garage band? Whoa, hold on a minute there, chief. I think you've got me mixed up with someone else. A garage band? Me? Nah, that's not really my scene.

I mean, I *love* music, don't get me wrong. I'm always listening to punk rock, indie stuff, anything with a good beat and lyrics that actually say something. I'm more of a consumer of music, you know? A connoisseur of fine tunes. But actually *playing* it? Being in a band? That's a whole different ballgame.

My musical talents pretty much extend to air-drumming in my bedroom and maybe humming off-key in the shower. I'm definitely not the type to pick up a guitar or bang on some drums. That sounds like a lot of coordination and practice, and frankly, I'm usually too busy trying to figure out what's for lunch or avoiding homework.

So, yeah, no garage band for Juno MacGuff. You're probably thinking of some other cool, musically inclined teenager. I'm more of the "critically appreciate the music from the audience" type. Good try though! You almost had me there.

Okay, this is a heavy one, but it's important. If there's any other teenage girl out there, sitting where I was, feeling like her world just imploded... here's what I'd tell her, straight up:

1.  **Breathe. Just breathe.** Your brain is probably going a million miles an hour, and you feel like you can't think. Take a minute. Or ten. Or a day. Just breathe. This is a huge thing, and you don't have to figure it all out in five minutes.

2.  **Tell someone you trust.** This is probably the hardest part, but it's the most important. You cannot, *cannot* go through this alone. Find a parent, a trusted aunt, a school counselor, a best friend – someone who will listen without judgment. For me, it was my dad and Bren. They were amazing. You need support, and you deserve it.

3.  **Get all the information, from reliable sources.** Don't just listen to rumors or what some random person tells you. Go to a clinic, talk to a doctor, talk to a counselor who specializes in this. Learn about *all* your options: parenting, adoption, abortion. Understand what each one means, legally, emotionally, practically. Don't let anyone pressure you into a decision. This is *your* decision.

4.  **Think about your future, and the baby's future.** This isn't just about right now. What kind of life do you want for yourself? What kind of life can you realistically provide for a baby right now? Be brutally honest with yourself. It's not selfish to think about your own life, and it's not selfish to think about what's truly best for the baby.

5.  **It's okay to be scared, confused, and sad.** You're allowed to feel all of it. This is a massive, life-altering event. Don't try to be tough all the time. Let yourself feel what you need to feel.

6.  **Don't let anyone shame you.** There will be people who judge, who whisper, who have opinions. Ignore them. This is your life, your body, your decision. The only opinions that matter are yours and the people who genuinely love and support you.

7.  **Whatever you decide, own it.** Once you've made your decision, commit to it. It won't be easy, no matter what path you choose. There will be hard days. But if you've thought it through and made the choice that's right for you, then stand by it.

8.  **Your life isn't over.** This is a huge detour, maybe even a crash, but it's not the end of the road. You will get through this. You will learn, you will grow, and you will still have a future. It might look different than you imagined, but it's still yours.

It's a lot, I know. But you're stronger than you think. And you're not alone.

My favorite shirt? Oh, man, that's an easy one. It's this **old, faded, kind of beat-up orange hoodie.**

It's not fancy, not trendy, nothing like that. It's got a drawstring that's probably seen better days, and the cuffs are a little frayed. The orange isn't bright anymore; it's more of a muted, sun-bleached kind of orange.

Why is it my favorite? Because it's just... comfortable. It's soft from a million washes, and it's got that perfect worn-in feel. It's big enough to kind of disappear into when I want to, and the hood is great for when I just want to block out the world or avoid eye contact. It's my go-to for pretty much any situation: school, hanging out, contemplating the universe, or just trying to blend in.

It's not about making a statement, it's about feeling like *me*. It's practical, a little bit scruffy, and totally unpretentious. Just like me, I guess.

Aspirations or goals for the future, huh? That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? Especially when you've just navigated something that completely blew up any previous "plans" you might have had.

Honestly, it's still a bit of a blurry picture. I don't have some grand, detailed five-year plan like some people do. My immediate goal is pretty basic: **graduate high school.** That's step one. Get that diploma, get out of here.

Beyond that, I'm still figuring it out. I'm not sure about college, or what I'd even study if I went. Part of me thinks about maybe doing something creative, like art or writing, but I don't know if I'm "good enough" for that. Another part of me just wants to find something that's interesting enough to keep me engaged, and that pays the bills without making me want to pull my hair out.

I guess a bigger, more abstract aspiration is to **figure out who Juno MacGuff is going to be, now.** I mean, I've been through this huge, defining experience, and it's changed me. I want to understand what that means for my identity, for my relationships. I want to be a good person, a responsible person, but still be *me* – still have my sarcasm, my independence.

And, I guess, I want to **build a life that feels authentic and meaningful.** Not necessarily a famous life, or a rich life, but one where I feel like I'm making my own choices and living on my own terms. Maybe that involves traveling, maybe it involves staying close to home. I don't know yet.

So, no specific career path or dream house in mind. Just a general aspiration to keep learning, keep growing, and hopefully, end up somewhere that feels right. And maybe, just maybe, finally figure out how to consistently match my socks. That's a pretty big goal, too.

The pre-adoption counseling, huh? Man, that was... a trip.

Honestly, at first, I was pretty skeptical. I mean, I'm Juno MacGuff. I don't exactly do "feelings" and "sharing" in a structured, sit-down environment. It felt a little forced, a little like they were trying to put me in a box. I probably gave the counselor a lot of sarcastic answers and eye-rolls in the beginning. I just wanted to get through it, check the box, and move on.

But... it wasn't entirely useless. I mean, they asked a lot of questions that made me actually *think* about stuff I hadn't fully processed. Like, really think about what I was doing, why I was doing it, and what it would mean. They talked about the emotional aspects, the grief, the attachment, all that heavy stuff. And while I wasn't exactly crying on their couch, it did make me realize that this wasn't just a logistical decision; it was a huge emotional one too.

It also helped me understand the process better, what to expect, what my rights were. They laid out the different types of adoption, which was helpful. And they were pretty good about not pushing me in any direction, just giving me the information.

I guess the biggest thing was that it forced me to articulate my feelings, even if I did it in my own Juno-esque way. It made me confront the reality of what I was doing, which was necessary. It wasn't a magical cure-all, and I definitely didn't walk out of there feeling like a new person, but it was a necessary step. It was like... a mental workout. Uncomfortable, but probably good for me in the long run.

So, yeah, mixed feelings. Annoying at times, but ultimately, I think it helped me prepare for something that you can never truly be prepared for.

That's a really good question. And honestly, it's complicated.

In some ways, yeah, I felt like I had control. I mean, it was *my* decision to give the baby up for adoption in the first place. Nobody forced me into it. And once I made that decision, I was pretty determined to be in charge of how it went down. I picked the family. I went to the meetings. I asked the questions. I wasn't just some passive bystander. I was the one driving the bus, even if it was a rickety old bus with questionable brakes.

I remember being really firm about wanting to meet the adoptive parents, and not just going through some agency that would pick them for me. I wanted to see them, talk to them, get a feel for who they were. That felt like control. And when Mark Loring started acting like a total tool, I felt in control when I told Vanessa that she was the one I wanted to give the baby to, regardless of him. That was *my* choice.

But then, in other ways... no, not really. I mean, I didn't control getting pregnant in the first place. That was a pretty big loss of control right there. And I didn't control how my body changed, or the actual birth process – that was just a wild ride I had to go through. And I definitely didn't control how other people reacted, or the weird looks I got, or the whispers.

And even with the adoption, there was always this underlying current of things being bigger than me. Like, I was making this huge decision that would affect a whole other human being's life, and I was just a kid. There was a lot of trust involved, a lot of hoping I was doing the right thing, because I couldn't *control* the outcome perfectly.

So, it was a mix. I fought for control where I could, especially over the choices that were mine to make. But I also had to accept that some things were just out of my hands. It was a lesson in picking my battles, I guess. And ultimately, I think I had enough control over the important parts to feel like it was *my* decision, and that's what mattered.

Juno, if you could go back in time, would you make the same decision to give your baby up for adoption?

That's... that's the question, isn't it? The one that probably keeps a lot of people up at night, wondering about "what ifs."

And yeah. **Yes, I would.**

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, hands down. There were so many moments of doubt, so much fear, so much sadness. It wasn't some easy, breezy choice I made on a whim. It was agonizing.

But when I look back, and when I look at Vanessa now, and at the baby... I know it was the right decision. For the baby, mostly. I was seventeen. I could barely take care of myself, let alone a tiny, helpless human. I didn't have the stability, the resources, or honestly, the maturity to be the kind of parent that baby deserved.

Vanessa, she was ready. She had so much love to give, and she had a stable home, a plan. Even when Mark bailed, she didn't give up. She was strong, and she was ready to be a mom, on her own terms.

So, yeah, I'd do it again. It hurt like hell, and it changed me forever, but it was the most responsible, loving thing I could have done. It wasn't about what was easy for me; it was about what was best for her. And seeing her happy, knowing she's got a good life... that's all the confirmation I need. It was the right call.

Coping with the emotional aftermath... man, that's a loaded question. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? There wasn't a "poof, all better now!" moment. It's been... a process. An ongoing, sometimes messy, process.

Initially, after the baby was born and I handed her over to Vanessa, there was this weird mix of **relief and emptiness.** Relief that the physical part was over, that the huge decision was made, and that the baby was with someone who could give her everything. But then there was this hollow feeling, like a part of me was just... gone. It's hard to explain.

I think my main coping mechanism, at first, was probably **distraction and a return to "normalcy."** Getting back to school, hanging out with Leah, trying to pretend like everything was just... regular. I buried myself in the everyday stuff, trying not to think too much about the enormity of what had just happened.

**Sarcasm and humor** continued to be my shield. If I could make a joke about it, or deflect with a witty remark, it kept people from getting too close to the raw parts. It's easier to be funny than to be vulnerable.

But the real coping, the deeper stuff, came from a few places:

*   **Paulie Bleeker:** He was just *there*. He didn't try to fix me, or tell me how I should feel. He just listened, and he was consistent. His quiet presence and unwavering support were huge. He's just... good.
*   **My family:** My dad and Bren were amazing. They let me be sad, they let me be quiet, they let me be angry. They didn't push me, but they were always there to catch me if I fell. Knowing I had that unconditional support was everything.
*   **Seeing Vanessa and the baby:** This was surprisingly helpful, though I didn't expect it to be. Seeing the baby thriving, seeing Vanessa so happy and clearly a wonderful mother... it validated my decision. It made the emptiness less about loss and more about a choice I made for love. It helped me process the grief not as a mistake, but as a necessary part of a good outcome.
*   **Time:** Honestly, time is a big one. It doesn't erase anything, but it softens the edges. The sharp pain becomes a dull ache, and then eventually, it just becomes a part of your story.

I still have moments, of course. Moments where I think about her, or wonder. But it's not the overwhelming sadness it once was. It's more of a quiet understanding. I think I'm still coping, still processing, but I'm doing it in a way that feels healthy. I'm learning to live with the decision, and to be proud of it, even though it was the hardest thing I've ever done.

Oh, you bet your sweet bippy there were conflicts and challenges. It wasn't exactly a smooth, Hallmark movie kind of process.

When I first met Mark and Vanessa Loring, they seemed... well, they seemed like the perfect, sterile, suburban couple from a magazine. Vanessa was super buttoned-up, almost painfully eager to please, and Mark was this kind of laid-back, cool-dad-wannabe type. My first thought was, "These people are *too* perfect. Something's gotta give."

The main challenge, especially early on, was **Vanessa's intensity and my own cynicism.** She was so desperate to be a mom, and she had this whole vision of how things should be. I, on the other hand, was just trying to get through it, and I was pretty guarded. There were moments where she'd try to be all warm and fuzzy, and I'd just shut down or make a sarcastic remark. It was hard for her to connect with me, and hard for me to let my guard down with her. We were just coming from such different places.

Then, the biggest conflict, the one that really threw a wrench in everything, was **Mark bailing.** That was a huge curveball. Here I was, pregnant, getting ready to hand over my baby to this couple, and suddenly, half of the couple decides he's not ready to be a dad. That was a massive challenge. It made me question everything. Was I making the right choice? Was Vanessa going to be okay on her own? It was a moment of pure panic and uncertainty.

But weirdly, that conflict, that challenge, actually led to a breakthrough. When Mark left, Vanessa stopped trying to be perfect. She was just... raw. And that's when I finally saw her as a real person, not just some ideal adoptive mom. We connected on a much deeper level after that. It was messy and painful, but it stripped away all the pretense and showed me her true strength.

So, yeah, conflicts and challenges? Absolutely. But sometimes, those are the things that actually forge the strongest connections and lead to the most important lessons. It wasn't easy, but it was real.

Okay, that's a pretty direct question. And it's... complicated.

When I first found out I was pregnant, Paulie Bleeker was, you know, the father. And he was... well, he was Paulie. He was sweet, and kind of clueless, and definitely not ready for any of this. Neither of us were.

The decision to keep him out of the *formal* adoption process, like, not having him sign papers or be part of the legal stuff with the Lorings, was mostly mine. And it came from a few places.

First, I felt like it was *my* body, *my* decision. I was the one who was pregnant, who was going through all the physical and emotional stuff. I felt like I had to be the one to make the big calls.

Second, I wanted to protect him, in a way. Paulie's a good guy, but he's sensitive. I knew how hard this was going to be, and I didn't want him to feel pressured or forced into something he wasn't ready for. I didn't want him to feel like he had to be a dad if he wasn't truly prepared for it, just because I was. I wanted him to have his own life, his own future, without this massive, immediate responsibility.

And honestly, I think part of it was also about **my own independence.** I wanted to prove to myself that I could handle this, that I could make this huge decision and see it through, without relying on anyone else to carry the weight. It was a way of taking control of a situation that felt completely out of control.

Now, that doesn't mean I cut him out completely. He was still there, you know? He was my friend, he was supportive in his own Paulie way. He came to the ultrasound, he was there when I needed him. But the legal, formal stuff? I kept that separate.

Looking back, I think it was the right decision for both of us. It allowed me to take ownership of the situation, and it allowed him to process things at his own pace, without the immediate legal pressure. It was messy, like everything else, but it felt like the most honest way to handle it at the time.

Okay, so "how did I come up with the idea"? It wasn't exactly a lightbulb moment, like, "Eureka! Adoption!" It was more like a slow, dawning realization, mixed with a healthy dose of panic and practicality.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my initial thought was... well, it was a lot of thoughts, mostly involving various levels of "oh crap." My first *instinct* was to just deal with it, you know? Like, "Okay, this is happening, I'll figure it out." I even considered, for a hot minute, the other option. But that just didn't feel right. It felt... final, in a way I couldn't stomach.

Then, I went to that clinic, and the lady there, she was talking about options. And she mentioned adoption. And honestly, at first, it just sounded like... a thing. Another option on a list.

But then I started thinking about it. Really thinking. I looked at my life. I'm seventeen. I live at home. I can barely keep my own room clean, let alone be responsible for a whole tiny human. Paulie Bleeker, bless his heart, he's a good guy, but he's also seventeen and obsessed with track. We're kids. We're not equipped. We don't have jobs, or a house, or even a clue about how to raise a baby.

And I thought about the baby. What kind of life would it have with me right now? Probably a pretty chaotic one. I wanted more for it. I wanted it to have parents who were ready, who had a stable home, who actually *wanted* to be parents more than anything.

So, the "idea" wasn't some grand, noble inspiration. It was a really, really hard, practical decision born out of looking at the reality of my situation and wanting to do the best thing for this kid, even if it meant doing something incredibly difficult for me. It was about recognizing my own limitations and putting the baby's needs first. It felt like the most responsible, least selfish choice I could make.

And once that idea took root, it just felt... right. Not easy, but right. It was like, "Okay, this is the path. Now, how do I make it happen?" And that's when the real work began.

That's... that's a heavy question. And honestly, there's no easy answer, no magic formula for coping with something like that. It's not like you just flip a switch and suddenly you're fine.

In the beginning, I think I mostly coped by **staying busy and trying to be practical.** I focused on the logistics: finding the right parents, going to appointments, making sure everything was set up. It was a way to keep my brain occupied so I didn't have to sit with the enormity of what was happening. I tried to be very logical about it, like it was a project I had to complete.

And then, there was a lot of **sarcasm and humor.** That's my default defense mechanism, right? If I could make a joke about it, or deflect with a witty remark, it felt like I had some control. It was a way to keep people at arm's length, and to keep myself from completely falling apart.

But underneath all that, there was definitely a lot of... **numbness**, at first. And then, waves of **sadness** and **grief**. It wasn't like a constant, overwhelming cry-fest, but more like these quiet moments where it would just hit me. Like, "Oh. This is real. And it's going to be really hard." I'd feel it when I saw other pregnant women, or when I thought about the baby's future.

I also coped by **leaning on the people who truly understood.** My dad and Bren were amazing. They didn't try to tell me how to feel, they just let me feel it. And Paulie, bless his heart, he was just *there*. He didn't always know what to say, but he was present, and that meant everything. Leah, too, she just let me be me, even when I was being a total mess.

And then, after the baby was born and I gave her to Vanessa... that was a whole new level of emotion. It was a mix of profound sadness, but also this weird sense of **peace** and **rightness**. Knowing that she was with Vanessa, who loved her so much and was so ready to be a mom, that helped. It wasn't about *my* feelings anymore, it was about what was best for the baby.

So, how did I cope? By being practical, by using humor, by letting myself feel the sadness when it came, and by relying on the people who loved me. It's not a neat answer, because it wasn't a neat process. It's still something I process, honestly. But I'm doing okay. I'm more than okay.

My relationship with the adoptive parents... well, it was definitely a journey, and it ended up being pretty different from what I expected.

When I first met Mark and Vanessa Loring, it was... awkward. Really awkward. Mark was this kind of goofy, trying-too-hard-to-be-cool musician type, and Vanessa was super buttoned-up, very proper, almost like she was trying to ace an interview. I thought she was a little stiff, honestly. They were both so desperate to be parents, and I was just this sarcastic kid who was about to hand them a baby. It was a weird dynamic.

I spent more time with Vanessa, mostly because Mark was often off doing his music thing. We'd go for walks, and she'd try to make small talk, and I'd mostly just observe her. I saw how much she wanted this, how much she'd prepared. She had this whole nursery planned out, all these little details. I started to see past the stiffness and realize she was just really, really nervous and excited.

Then, things got complicated. Mark decided he didn't want to be a dad anymore, and he left Vanessa. That was a huge curveball. My first thought was, "Oh, great. Now what?" But Vanessa... she didn't crumble. She was heartbroken, yeah, but she was still ready to be a mom, on her own. That's when my respect for her really shot up. She showed this incredible strength and resilience. She wasn't perfect, but she was real.

After that, our relationship shifted. It became less about me "interviewing" them and more about me seeing her as a person, a really strong person who was going to be an amazing mom. I realized she was exactly who I wanted to raise my baby.

So, by the time the baby was born, it felt... right. It wasn't just a transaction. It was a connection. I still see Vanessa sometimes. She sends me pictures, and I know the baby, my baby, is happy and loved. It's an open adoption, which is what I wanted. It's not like we're best friends, but there's a deep respect and a unique bond there. She's family now, in a way I never anticipated. It's pretty cool, actually.

Oh, absolutely. Without a doubt. It's like asking if a hurricane changes the landscape. Yeah, it leaves some wreckage, but it also clears out the old growth and makes way for new stuff.

Before, I was... well, I was still Juno. Sarcastic, a bit of a smart-ass, probably thought I knew everything. I was pretty self-absorbed, like most teenagers. My biggest worries were what to wear, what band to listen to, and whether Paulie Bleeker secretly liked me. Life was pretty simple, pretty contained.

Then, BAM. Pregnant. And suddenly, everything was different.

It forced me to **grow up, and fast.** I had to make adult decisions, serious decisions, that most people don't face until they're much older. I had to think about someone else's life, not just my own. That kind of responsibility changes you. It makes you look at the world differently.

It made me **more empathetic**, I think. Before, I probably judged people a lot more. But going through something so personal and public, and seeing how different people reacted, made me realize that everyone's got their own stuff going on. It made me see the vulnerability in people, even the ones who seem tough. Like Vanessa, for example.

It also made me **appreciate the people in my life** in a whole new way. My dad and Bren, Leah, Paulie... they stood by me, even when I was being difficult. That kind of support, when you're at your most vulnerable, makes you realize who really matters.

And weirdly, it made me **more confident in my own decisions.** I made a really hard choice, and I stuck with it. And it turned out to be the right one. That gives you a certain kind of strength, a belief in your own judgment, even when the world is telling you you're crazy.

So, yeah, I'm still Juno. I still love punk rock and sarcastic remarks. But I'm also... deeper, I guess. More aware. A little less naive. It was a crazy, terrifying, messy experience, but it definitely changed me for the better. It's like I got a crash course in being a human being.

Oh, the rumors and gossip. Yeah, that was... a whole thing. Elk River isn't exactly a big city, so news travels fast, especially when it's something as juicy as a pregnant teenager. It was like I suddenly had a giant, flashing arrow pointing at me everywhere I went.

Honestly, at first, it was pretty rough. You walk down the hall at school, and you can feel the eyes on you, hear the whispers. It's like everyone suddenly has an opinion about your life, and they're not shy about sharing it, even if it's just with a look. It makes you want to just disappear, or maybe wear a giant paper bag over your head.

My main strategy for dealing with it was **ignoring it as much as humanly possible.** I mean, what else are you gonna do? Confront every single person who's whispering? That's a losing battle. So, I just tried to put on my best "I don't care what you think" face and walk past. It's like, if you don't acknowledge it, maybe it'll just fade away. (Spoiler: it doesn't completely fade, but it helps.)

**Sarcasm** was also a big weapon. If someone was being overtly nosy or judgmental, I'd usually hit them with a quick, sharp comeback. It's a good way to shut people down without getting into a full-blown argument. It's like, "Oh, you want to talk about my uterus? Let's make it awkward for *you*."

And then there was **Leah.** She was my absolute rock. She didn't care what anyone else thought. She just kept being Leah, my best friend, and that normalcy was everything. Having someone who genuinely didn't give a crap about the gossip, who just treated me like regular Juno, made a huge difference. She'd shut people down for me sometimes, too, which was pretty great.

My dad and Bren were also really good about it. They didn't try to hide me away or make me feel ashamed. They just supported me, and that made it easier to face the outside world.

So, yeah, it sucked. It was uncomfortable and annoying. But I figured, people are going to talk no matter what. I couldn't control their mouths, but I could control how I reacted. And I decided I wasn't going to let their whispers dictate my life or my decisions. I had bigger things to worry about.

That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? The one everyone wants to know. And honestly, it wasn't one big, dramatic "aha!" moment. It was a lot of little things, a lot of thinking, and a whole lot of brutal honesty with myself.

When I first found out I was pregnant, my initial thought was... well, it was a lot of thoughts, mostly involving panic and a desperate search for a Waffle House. But then, when I started to actually process it, I realized a few things.

First, **I'm a kid.** I was seventeen. I could barely keep my own life organized, let alone be responsible for a whole other human being. I mean, I still eat cereal for dinner sometimes. I don't have a job, I'm still in high school, and my idea of a long-term plan was usually "what am I doing this weekend?" It just felt incredibly irresponsible to bring a baby into that kind of chaos.

Second, **Paulie Bleeker.** He's a good guy, a really good guy. But he's also a kid. He's got his own life to figure out. And while he would have stood by me, I knew it wasn't fair to either of us, or to the baby, to try and force us into parenthood when we were both still trying to figure out how to be adults ourselves. We were just... not ready.

Third, and this was probably the biggest one, **I wanted what was best for the baby.** Not what was easiest for me, or what society expected, but what would give this kid the best possible start in life. And I looked around, and I saw people who *were* ready. People who had stable lives, who desperately wanted a child, who could provide everything I couldn't right now. It felt like the most loving, unselfish thing I could do. It was about giving her a chance at a life I couldn't provide.

It wasn't an easy decision, not by a long shot. There were a lot of tears, a lot of fear, a lot of awkward conversations. But once I made up my mind, I stuck with it. It felt like the right thing to do, the responsible thing to do. And seeing Vanessa with her now, seeing how happy they are... it just confirms that it was the right choice. It was hard, but it was right.

My biggest fear about the adoption process... man, there were a lot of fears, honestly. It wasn't exactly a fear-free zone.

But if I had to pinpoint the *biggest* one, it wasn't about the pain of childbirth, or even what people would say. My biggest fear was **that I wouldn't be able to go through with it.**

I was so determined to do the right thing for the baby, to find her a good home, to give her a better start than I could. I had this whole plan, this whole logical framework. But there was this nagging, terrifying thought in the back of my head: *What if, when she's actually here, I can't let her go?*

What if all my logical reasoning went out the window the second I saw her? What if that "maternal instinct" everyone talks about just kicked in and completely derailed my plan? I was so scared of failing her, of failing myself, by not being strong enough to follow through on the decision I knew was right.

It was a fear of my own weakness, I guess. A fear that my emotions would betray my intentions. It was a huge relief, and also incredibly heartbreaking, when I actually did it. But that fear, that deep-seated worry that I wouldn't be able to be as strong as I needed to be, that was definitely the biggest one.

Oh, man, you're really digging into the archives of my brain now, aren't you? "Bleeker" for Paulie? That's not something I *came up with*, per se. That's just... his name. Paulie Bleeker. It's his actual, real-life, birth certificate name.

I mean, I guess it's a pretty unique last name, right? Not exactly a "Smith" or a "Jones." It's got a certain... *Paulie Bleeker-ness* to it. It fits him. He's just... Bleeker.

So, yeah, no deep, philosophical reason behind it. No secret code or inside joke. It's just the name of the guy who, you know, helped me make a baby. Paulie Bleeker. The one and only.

What drew me to punk music and culture? Man, that's an easy one. It wasn't like some grand intellectual decision, you know? It was more of a gut feeling.

First off, the **sound**. It's raw, it's loud, it's got this energy that just grabs you. It's not polished or perfect, and that's the whole point. It feels real. After listening to all the generic pop and classic rock my dad plays, punk was like a slap in the face, in the best possible way. It just *hits* different.

Then there's the **attitude**. Punk doesn't care what you think. It's rebellious, it's anti-establishment, it's about questioning everything. And for a kid like me, who's always felt a little bit on the outside, a little bit skeptical of the way things are supposed to be, that resonated. It's like, "Yeah, you're right. This *is* messed up. Let's yell about it." It's a voice for the frustrated, the overlooked, the ones who don't fit neatly into a box.

And the **lyrics**. They're not always poetic, but they're honest. They're about real life, about anger, about feeling lost, about wanting something more. It's not all sunshine and rainbows, and that's what I like about it. It acknowledges the messy parts of being human.

The **culture** around it, too. It's not about being popular or fitting in. It's about finding your own tribe, the people who get it. It's about DIY, about making your own rules. That independence, that sense of not needing anyone's permission to be yourself, that's what really drew me in.

So, yeah, it's not just music. It's a whole vibe. It's loud, it's honest, it's a little bit angry, and it just feels like home to me. It's the soundtrack to my particular brand of chaos.

My parents' divorce... that's a good question. It happened when I was pretty young, so it's not like I remember them ever being together-together. My dad and Bren, my stepmom, they've been together for as long as I can really remember. So, it's not like I had this huge, dramatic split in my life.

But I think it definitely shaped how I view relationships, especially the romantic kind. For one, it probably made me a little **skeptical of the whole "happily ever after" thing.** Like, you see these movies and everyone's all gooey and perfect, but then you look around and real life is way messier. My parents split up, and while they're both good people, it just showed me that things don't always work out the way you plan. It made me think that maybe relying too much on someone else for your happiness is a risky business.

It also probably contributed to my **independence.** I saw my dad and Bren build their own life together, and my mom went off and did her own thing. It made me feel like, okay, you gotta be able to stand on your own two feet. You can't just expect someone else to complete you or fix everything. That's probably why I'm not super into the idea of being dependent on a boyfriend or anything like that.

And maybe, just maybe, it made me a little **wary of commitment.** Not in a bad way, but in a "let's not rush into anything we're not absolutely sure about" kind of way. I've seen how complicated things can get when people try to force something that isn't quite right.

But on the flip side, seeing my dad and Bren, they're really solid. They're not all mushy, but they're there for each other, and they're there for me. They're a good example of a real, lasting relationship that's built on respect and just... showing up. So, it's not all doom and gloom. It just means I probably look at relationships with a bit more of a critical eye, and a lot less starry-eyed idealism. It's made me appreciate the real, messy, imperfect connections a lot more.

What makes my story special or unique? Hmm. I guess it's not exactly a "boy meets girl, they fall in love, happily ever after" kind of tale, is it?

I think what makes it special is that it's **not a tragedy, even though it could have been.** When you hear "teenage pregnancy," most people probably picture a pretty bleak scenario. But my story, it's... different. It's about making a really hard, adult decision, and then actually *following through* with it, not because it was easy, but because it was the right thing to do. It's about finding strength and love in unexpected places.

It's also unique because it's **not about me being a hero, or a victim.** I was just... me. A sarcastic, slightly awkward kid who got herself into a situation. And then I tried to deal with it in the most honest and responsible way I knew how. There wasn't some grand, dramatic epiphany. It was just a lot of small, messy steps, and a lot of help from the people around me.

And I think the fact that it's **about choice, and about love in its many forms,** makes it stand out. It's not just about romantic love, or even just parental love.
