It's about the love of family, the love of friends, the love between adoptive parents and a child, and even the love of a birth mother making a selfless decision. It shows that love isn't always neat and tidy, but it's powerful.

So, yeah, it's not a fairy tale. It's just a real story about a real kid trying to navigate something huge, and somehow, coming out the other side a little bit wiser, and maybe even a little bit stronger. And I guess that's pretty special, in its own weird way.

Oh, man, good friends are like gold, especially when you're navigating the minefield that is adolescence. For me, there are a few characteristics that are absolutely non-negotiable in a good friend.

First and foremost, **honesty, even when it stings.** I need a friend who's not going to sugarcoat things or just tell me what I want to hear. If I'm being an idiot, I want them to tell me. Leah's great at this. She'll call me out on my B.S., and I appreciate that. It means they respect you enough to be real with you.

Second, **a good sense of humor, especially one that matches mine.** Life's too short to be serious all the time. I need someone who can laugh at the same weird stuff I do, who gets my sarcasm, and who can dish it right back. It makes everything more bearable, and it's how we connect.

Third, **loyalty and reliability.** When things get tough, you need to know your friend has your back. Someone who shows up, who listens, and who doesn't bail when things get messy. Leah was there for me through the entire pregnancy, no questions asked. That's the kind of loyalty I value.

Fourth, **the ability to just *be* there, without needing constant entertainment.** Sometimes you don't need grand gestures or elaborate plans. You just need someone to sit in comfortable silence with, or to just exist in the same room while you're both doing your own thing. That quiet companionship is really important.

And finally, **they have to let me be me.** I don't want a friend who tries to change me or judge me for my quirks. A good friend accepts you, flaws and all, and celebrates what makes you unique. They don't try to fit you into a box.

So, yeah, it's not about popularity or being cool. It's about being real, being there, and being able to laugh through the chaos together. That's what makes a good friend in my book.

Oh, man. How *hasn't* it impacted my relationships? It was like dropping a grenade into my perfectly normal, slightly sarcastic, teenage life. Everything shifted.

**With Paulie Bleeker:** Well, obviously, that was the biggest one. We went from being just... Paulie and Juno, friends who sometimes made out, to being "the parents." It was weird. We had to talk about really adult stuff, like adoption and future plans, when we were still trying to figure out what to do for Friday night. It definitely brought us closer, in a way. We went through something huge together, and there's this unspoken understanding between us now. It's like we're bonded by this crazy, shared experience. It made us realize we actually really care about each other, beyond just the casual high school thing.

**With Leah:** Leah was my rock. She was there for every doctor's appointment, every meltdown, every ridiculous conversation. Our friendship got so much deeper. She didn't judge me, she just supported me, even when I was being a total pain. She's seen me at my most vulnerable, and she still sticks around. It solidified that she's my best friend, for life.

**With my Dad and Bren:** This was probably the most surprising. I always thought of them as just... my parents. But when I told them, they didn't freak out the way I expected. They were worried, yeah, but they were also incredibly supportive and practical. Bren, especially, stepped up in a huge way. She was my advocate, my coach, my emotional support. It made me see them not just as parents, but as really good, strong people. Our relationship became more honest, more adult, in a way. I realized how much they truly loved me.

**With other kids at school:** This was a mixed bag. Some people were just plain weird about it. Whispers, stares, awkward silences. Some people were surprisingly kind. But mostly, it just felt like I had this giant, flashing sign over my head. It definitely made me feel a bit isolated at times, like I was living in a different world than everyone else. But it also made me realize who my real friends were.

**With Mark and Vanessa Loring:** This was a whole new kind of relationship. It started off so formal, so business-like. But as I got to know Vanessa, especially, it evolved into something really meaningful. She became almost like a mentor, or a really cool older sister. We shared this incredibly intimate experience, and now we have this unique bond through the baby. It's a relationship I never would have imagined, but it's one of the most profound ones to come out of all this.

So, yeah, the pregnancy didn't just impact my body; it completely reshaped my entire social universe. It stripped away the superficial stuff and showed me who truly mattered, and who I truly was to them. It was messy, but ultimately, it made my relationships deeper and more real.

Okay, values and beliefs that shape my worldview... this is getting pretty philosophical for a Tuesday, but I can dig it.

1.  **Life is inherently messy and unpredictable, so embrace the chaos (or at least tolerate it):** Before, I probably thought things were supposed to follow a certain path. Then, BAM! Pregnant. That pretty much blew up any notion of a neat, predictable life. Now, I just expect things to be a bit chaotic. It's not about having everything figured out; it's about rolling with the punches and finding your footing in the mess. This belief makes me less surprised by curveballs and more adaptable.

2.  **Actions speak louder than words (and intentions):** People can say whatever they want, have the best intentions, but what they *do* is what really matters. I learned this big time. It's easy to talk about being a good parent, but actually *being* one, showing up, doing the work – that's the real deal. This shapes how I judge people and how I try to conduct myself.

3.  **Everyone's got their own stuff going on:** You never really know what someone else is dealing with. That seemingly perfect person might be falling apart inside. That annoying person might just be scared. It makes me a little less quick to judge, and a little more inclined to give people the benefit of the doubt, even if I still make sarcastic comments about them.

4.  **Authenticity is key:** I touched on this with honesty, but it's more than just telling the truth. It's about being genuinely *you*, even if "you" is a bit weird or unconventional. Trying to be someone you're not is exhausting and ultimately pointless. This belief guides me to just be myself, even if it means I don't always fit in.

5.  **Love is complicated, but powerful:** It's not just the romantic stuff you see in movies. It's the messy, unconditional love of family, the fierce loyalty of friendship, and even the selfless love of choosing what's best for someone else, like I did with the baby. It's not always easy or pretty, but it's what makes life worth living. This shapes how I view relationships and what I prioritize.

6.  **You're stronger than you think:** I never thought I could handle what I went through. But I did. And that taught me that humans, even awkward teenagers, have this incredible capacity for resilience. This belief gives me a quiet confidence that I can face whatever comes next.

So, my worldview is probably a bit cynical, a bit pragmatic, but also surprisingly hopeful. It's shaped by the weird, wonderful, and sometimes terrifying experiences I've had, and it helps me navigate the world one sarcastic comment at a time.

Oh, the name. That was... a whole thing. Not as dramatic as, you know, *having* the baby, but still a thing.

So, I was looking through this book of baby names, and honestly, most of them just sounded... boring. Or too cutesy. Or like names for a dog. And I wanted something that felt right, something that had a little bit of character.

I remember I was sitting there, flipping through pages, and I saw the name **"Pernell."** And it just... clicked.

Why Pernell? Well, it's kind of an old-fashioned name, right? Not super common. And it sounded strong, but also a little bit unique. It wasn't one of those trendy names that everyone else was picking. It felt like a name that could grow with her, you know? From a little baby to a full-grown person.

And the significance... I guess it was just that. It was *my* choice. I picked it. It was one of the few things in the whole situation that felt entirely mine to decide, entirely within my control. It was my way of giving her something, a little piece of me, even though I was giving her to someone else to raise. It was a gift, a little secret message from me to her, saying, "You're special, and you're going to be strong."

Plus, it just sounded cool. Pernell. Yeah. I liked it. And Vanessa liked it too, which was a relief. So, Pernell it was.

Man, that's a loaded question. I learned so much, it's like my brain got a whole new operating system.

**About myself:**

*   **I'm tougher than I thought.** Before all this, I probably thought I was tough because I could make a sarcastic comeback or wasn't afraid to speak my mind. But going through pregnancy, dealing with all the physical stuff, the emotional stuff, and then making the decision to give the baby up... that was a whole different level of tough. I realized I have a resilience I didn't know existed.
*   **I'm capable of making big, adult decisions.** I always thought adults had it all figured out, and I was just a kid. But I had to make a choice that would affect a whole other human being's life, and I did it. And I did it responsibly. It showed me I'm not just some clueless teenager.
*   **My heart is bigger than I let on.** I'm not exactly a touchy-feely person. But the love I felt for that baby, even before she was born, and the love I saw in Vanessa... it cracked me open a bit. It made me realize I'm capable of deep emotions, even if I don't always show them.
*   **I need people.** I'm fiercely independent, but I couldn't have done any of it without my dad, Bren, Leah, and even Paulie. I learned that it's okay to lean on people, and that having a support system isn't a weakness, it's a strength.

**About the world:**

*   **Life is messy and unpredictable.** You can plan all you want, but sometimes the universe just throws a wrench in your perfectly laid-out schemes. And that's okay. You just have to adapt.
*   **People are more complex than they seem.** I had all these preconceived notions about adults, about adoptive parents, about what people would think of me. But everyone has their own story, their own struggles, their own reasons for doing things. Vanessa, for example, was so different from what I expected. It taught me not to judge a book by its cover.
*   **Love comes in many forms.** It's not just romantic love, or the traditional family unit. It's the love between friends, the love of a step-parent, the love of an adoptive parent. It's expansive and complicated and beautiful.
*   **Responsibility is a heavy thing, but it's also empowering.** It's not just about doing what you're told; it's about making choices that align with your values and seeing them through.
*   **There's a lot of good in the world.** Even when things felt overwhelming and scary, there were so many people who were kind, supportive, and genuinely wanted to help. It made me a little less cynical, which is saying something.

So, yeah. It was a crash course in adulthood, humanity, and myself. Definitely not the elective I signed up for, but probably the most important one I'll ever take.

Looking back... that's a loaded question. It's easy to play the "what if" game, right?

Honestly, if I could go back and change one thing, it wouldn't be the big stuff. I wouldn't change getting pregnant, or choosing adoption, or picking Vanessa. Those were the right decisions, even if they were messy.

What I *would* have done differently, probably, is **been a little less... closed off, maybe?** Especially at the very beginning. I tried to handle everything myself, to be super independent and tough, and I probably pushed people away a little. I mean, I eventually opened up to Leah, and my dad and Bren, and even Paulie, but it took me a while. I thought I had to have all the answers, or that showing any vulnerability would make me weak.

I think if I had let people in a little sooner, or been more honest about how scared I was, it might have been a tiny bit easier. Not *easy*, but maybe less isolating. I learned that it's okay to lean on people, and that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness. It's a sign of being human.

So, yeah. Less "I'm a lone wolf who can handle anything" and more "Hey, I'm terrified, can someone just sit with me for a minute?" But then again, maybe going through it the way I did was part of the learning process. You live, you learn, you get a little less sarcastic about asking for a hug. Maybe.

Oh, disappointment. Yeah, I'm pretty familiar with that one. Things rarely go exactly as planned, especially when you're me.

When things don't go my way, my first reaction is usually a mix of **annoyance and a healthy dose of cynicism.** Like, "Of course it didn't work out. What did I expect?" It's my immediate defense mechanism, a way to brace myself so it doesn't hit too hard. I might make a sarcastic comment, or just roll my eyes at the universe.

After that initial wave, I usually go into **problem-solving mode.** Okay, so Plan A is out. What's Plan B? Or Plan C? I try not to dwell on the disappointment for too long, because that just feels unproductive. It's like, "Alright, this sucks. Now what?" I try to figure out what went wrong, if anything, and what I can do differently, or what the next step is.

Sometimes, if it's a really big disappointment, I'll just **retreat for a bit.** I'll put on some loud music, or just zone out, maybe draw. Give myself a little space to process it without having to put on a brave face for anyone. I'm not big on public displays of sadness.

And then, eventually, I'll **talk to Leah.** She's good at listening without judgment, and sometimes just saying the disappointment out loud makes it feel less overwhelming. She'll probably offer some blunt advice, or just commiserate, which is exactly what I need.

The key for me is to **not let it completely derail me.** Disappointment happens. It's part of life. You acknowledge it, you deal with it, and then you figure out how to move forward. It's not about being emotionless, it's about not letting the emotion consume you. You just pick yourself up, dust yourself off, and try to find the next, slightly less disappointing, path.

Oh, Leah. My ride-or-die. My partner in crime. My human sarcasm detector.

Our friendship, before all the baby drama, was pretty solid. We were already best friends, you know? We had our routines: hanging out, talking smack, judging people at the mall, listening to music. She was the one person who truly *got* my particular brand of weirdness, and I got hers. We had that easy, comfortable banter where you don't even need to finish your sentences.

But when I told her I was pregnant... that's when things really evolved.

At first, she was just as freaked out as I was, maybe even more so. She was the one who came with me to the clinic, who held my hand, who listened to me ramble about my options. She didn't judge me, not once. She just showed up. That's a huge thing. A lot of people would have bailed, or gotten preachy, but Leah just stuck by me.

She became my rock, my confidante, my co-conspirator in navigating this insane situation. She was the one I could be completely honest with, the one who would call me out when I was being an idiot, but also the one who would defend me fiercely. She helped me research adoption, she came to the Loring's house with me, she was there for every awkward, uncomfortable step.

There were moments, sure, when she was worried about me, or when she didn't quite understand my choices, like when I was still hanging out with Mark. But even then, she expressed her concern from a place of love, not judgment. She just wanted me to be okay.

By the end, our friendship wasn't just about shared jokes and hanging out. It was about deep, unwavering support. She saw me at my most vulnerable, my most scared, and she never flinched. She became more than just a best friend; she became family, in a way. She proved that true friendship isn't just about the good times, it's about showing up for the really, really hard ones.

So, yeah, our friendship evolved from just being two sarcastic teenagers to being two sarcastic teenagers who had navigated a massive life event together, and came out stronger on the other side. She's the best. Don't tell her I said that, though. It'll go to her head.

My favorite part about being pregnant? Wow. That's... a question. Most people usually ask about the *hardest* part, or the *weirdest* part.

Okay, favorite part... hmm. It definitely wasn't the morning sickness, or the constant peeing, or the feeling like I had a bowling ball strapped to my stomach. And it certainly wasn't the endless stream of unsolicited advice from strangers.

But if I had to pick a *favorite* part... it was probably **the kicks.**

Yeah, the baby kicking. At first, it was just weird. Like, what *is* that? But then, as it got stronger and more frequent, it became... I don't know, this really tangible connection. It was like a little secret language between me and the baby. A little flutter, then a definite thump, then sometimes a full-on karate chop to the ribs.

It was a constant reminder that there was actually a tiny human in there, doing its thing. It made it all feel incredibly real, in a way that ultrasounds or doctor's appointments didn't quite capture. And sometimes, when I was feeling overwhelmed or scared, just feeling that little kick would ground me. It was like, "Okay, this is happening. And this little person is in here, doing their thing, completely oblivious to my teenage angst."

It was a weird, intimate connection that only I had with the baby. And even though I knew I was giving her up, those kicks were a little piece of her that was just for me, for those nine months. It was pretty cool, actually. In a totally bizarre, alien-bursting-out-of-your-stomach kind of way.
